sourceMeaningMnemonic: There’s a <radical>stone</radical>, a <radical>tree</radical>, another <radical>tree</radical>, and a <radical>coat rack</radical>. That stone and two trees will make the perfect <kanji>foundation</kanji>, or <kanji>cornerstone</kanji>, for a house to put that coat rack in! This stone is flat and heavy and both of the trees are flexible and durable.
meaningInfo: Imagine making a foundation with the stone and the two trees so you’ll have a place for your coat rack. Feel the wood grain and cold stone against your skin as you move them around to form the foundation.
readingMnemonic: After you finish the <kanji>foundation</kanji>, the only step that's left is to wash the entire thing with <reading>so</reading>ap (<ja>そ</ja>).
readingInfo: Imagine getting on your hands and knees, rubbing a bar of soap all over the foundation you built. The soap gets into all the nooks and crannies in the wood and stone. Now if a coat falls off the coat rack onto the floor, you just add water and poof! Clean!
